column4: hi, I don't have the correct permissions to write to files in my homedir, I get permission denied errors. How can I fix this?
sudo chown yourusername filename
it appears to be all files in my homedir, is there a recursive option?
chown -R yourusername *
thanks. do you have any idea why I don't have permission? I can't even mv or rm files that I own..
i dunno. what does "ls -l filename" show on such files?
it shows that I am the owner of all files
what about the permissions?
everything is chmod 775 at least
what about the permissions/ownership of the parent directory?
directory /home/username is dr-xr-xr-x
I am in the failsafe at the moment, as gnome doesnt load. just kicks me back to the login prompt
i think there's a "w" missing there for the owner
my home directories are drwxr-xr-x
i see ok, i'll give it a try thanks
the fourth column in the ls -l display, is that the creator or owner?
owner
wait a moment, *fourth* column? that's neither. that's the group
I see, because a few of the directories have that as root
also what is the default chmod for a directory?
you should probably change that to your user, for files in your home. though it shouldn't really hurt. (note that there are groups with the same name as users, by default)
